citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes durhamensis sp. nov.
Actinoplanes durhamensis (dur. ham.en'sis. ML adj. durhamensis, belonging to Durham, a city in the North-East of England)
Light to dark orange substrate mycelium formed on modified Bennett's agar.
Sporangia globose, spores motile and arranged irregularly within sporangia.

Degrades arbutin, casein, lecithin and starch; utilizes L-arabinose, dextrin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, meso-inositol, D-lactose, D-maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, D-melezitose, methyl β-D-glucoside, raffinose, L-rhamnose, D-sorbitol, D-xylose and p-hydroxybenzoic acid as sole carbon sources but not D-cellobiose, erythritol, catechol, coumarin, o-hydroxybenzoic acid, sodium fumarate, sodium succinate, syringaldehyde, syringic acid or vanillin.
Neither hydrogen sulphide nor urease is formed.
The organism is sensitive to a number of antibiotics and chemical inhibitors (Table 6) and shows activity against Staphylococcus aureus.
It grows at 4 and 30 °C, but not at 37 °C.
The peptidoglycan contains meso- and hydroxydiaminopimelic acid.
The principal wall sugars are arabinose, galactose, glucose, mannose and xylose.

The organism also contains complex mixtures of straight- and branched-chain fatty acids, with octadecanoic, 14- methylpentadecanoic and 14-methylhexadecanoic acids predominating, tetrahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units as the predominant isoprenologue, and major amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
Type strain: Actinoplanes durhamensis LA 139 (IFO 14914, NCIB 20041).
